A painting by De Heem cost 2,000 guilders, or 1,476 grams of gold. By way of comparison, the two most expensive of the 299 works sold in the seventeenth century in the present data set are: Rubens, The Bath of Diana. The figures are above half the size of nature, sold to Cardinal Richelieu in 1642 for the equivalent of 4,393 grams of gold and Van Dyck, An Equestrian portrait of Charles I. The monarch is seen in nearly a front view, with his head uncovered, and his dark hair flowing on a rich lace frill, which encircles the neck, and forms a fine relief to the brilliant suit of armour in which he is clad, sold in 1651 for the equivalent of 1,464 grams of gold
